newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish peasants keep Pawlak as party leader.
newsitem.headline: Polish peasants keep Pawlak as party leader.

text.p: The Polish Peasant Party, junior partner in the ruling left-wing coalition, reelected Waldemar Pawlak as leader on Saturday.
Results announced in the small hours and reported by PAP news agency showed 695 delgates at a party convention voted to give the 37-year old Pawlak four more years in the post.
Agriculture Minister Roman Jagielinski got 402 votes and 120 delegates backed another challenger, Janusz Piechocinski.
"I know I made mistakes, but I also know that I did not betray Poland or the peasants," Pawlak told delegates before the vote, winning a standing ovation, Gazeta Wyborcza reported.
As prime minister until early last year in coalition with the ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance, Pawlak was accused by critics of braking market reforms and hampering privatisation.
But he remains popular among farmers as the man who led the Peasants to a strong showing in the 1993 elections and whose policies allowed many of the party's members to gain government posts.
Opinion polls have indicated for months that the Peasants, backed by around 15 percent of voters, are likely to hold the balance of power after a general election next year.
The convention also overwhelmingly re-elected parliamentary speaker Jozef Zych as the chairman of the party's council.
